pages.text: Fire, the jumpstarter of civilization.$(br2)There is no end to the utility of fire, so I must also have many ways to go about starting fires as well if I am to survive in any environment.$(br2)Here, I have noted a few methods of creating fire:
Let's start off basic: snapping a stick in two will enable me to make some basic firestarters, as can be seen on the next page.

Combining the broken stick with $(thing)dried fibers$() gets me a hand drill, good for a quick and dirty fire. My arms get a bit tired after using one though, so it's not the most efficient thing in the world.

A $(thing)fire charge$(), made with the powdery substance from a creeper and a hunk of $(thing)coal$(). A handy recipe for those moments when I'm deep underground without surface materials. They can be thrown, too, at the risk of self-ignition.

The superior firestarter, made with a chunk of $(thing)flint$() from gravel and a old piece of $(thing)steel$() dropped from some undead. Unlike previous methods listed, this can be reused many times. The people of the past must have carried these around.

As for its applications, I've so far thought of several ways to utilize fire:$(br2)1. Placing some $(thing)dried fibers$() on the ground and surrounding it with logs, then lighting it. Makes for an easy $(thing)campfire$() to cook with and relax by, though the logs burn out eventually.$(br2)2. Heating up a $(thing)cooking cauldron$(), $(thing)crucible$(), or $(thing)soaking pot$() by lighting a fire directly underneath.

3. Lighting defensive fires around my dwelling as a monster deterrent. Some monsters may not be harmed by fire, so this shouldn't be relied upon all the time.$(br2)4. Starting a fire to clear out brush and foliage. I would have to be very careful however, as I can easily end up accidentally decimating the terrain and thus depriving myself of its natural resources.
